abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Second Rural
            Development Project for Sri Lanka was successful. The main
            objective, to improve the productivity, income, and living
            standards of people in the Puttalam and Matale districts,
            was achieved. Implementation of the project was deemed
            satisfactory even though there were delays. The project is
            sustainable for the future. Both the Borrower and the Bank
            acted effectively. Several lessons can be learned from this
            experience. First, the project confirms that the approach
            taken to achieve a broad-based development of Sri
            Lanka's districts, initiated under the Kurunegala Rural
            Development Project, is appropriate and replicable under the
            country's conditions. Second, project design should
            have focused more clearly on organization and management
            aspects to ensure effective coordination among the multiple
            line agencies. Third, the project would have been easier to
            supervise if it did not include such a wide and diverse
            range of subprojects. Lastly, the project period should have
            been longer than envisaged due to implementation delays that
            arose when a large number of agencies were involved and
            funds were in short supply.
